reviews.text: The trip to Badrinath Temple on a chilly cold night was both mystical and exhilarating. The cold air added a sense of mystery and anticipation to the visit, making the temple's spiritual significance even more profound. Walking through the dimly lit pathways under the starry sky created a magical ambiance that heightened the sense of reverence and awe. The sound of bells ringing in the cold night air added a sense of spirituality to the experience. Despite the freezing temperatures, the warmth of devotion and faith kept us going as we offered our prayers at the sacred temple. The Badrinath Temple trip in the chilly cold night was a truly enchanting and unforgettable experience that will be remembered for a lifetime.

My review of the Badrinath temple will depend on several factors, like your priorities and expectations. What are you most interested in? Spiritual experience, architectural beauty, natural surroundings, or the journey itself
During peak season, the temple can get very crowded, making it difficult to get a close glimpse of the idol.
Visiting Badrinath temple is a unique and unforgettable experience, especially for those with spiritual inclinations or a love for nature. However, it's important to be prepared for the potential challenges and manage your expectations regarding facilities and crowds

reviews.text:
Visiting Badrinath, a sacred town in the Chamoli district of Uttarakhand, India, is a deeply spiritual and culturally enriching experience for tourists. Here are some highlights of the tourist experience in Badrinath:

Spiritual Journey: Badrinath is one of the Char Dham pilgrimage sites and holds immense significance in Hindu mythology. Tourists can explore the ancient Badrinath Temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu, soak in the spiritual atmosphere, and participate in prayers and rituals.

Natural Beauty: Nestled in the Garhwal Himalayas, Badrinath offers breathtaking views of snow-capped peaks, pristine rivers, and lush greenery. Tourists can indulge in trekking, photography, and nature walks to immerse themselves in the serene beauty of the surroundings.

Hot Springs: Mana, the last village before the Indo-China border, is known for its natural hot water springs called Tapt Kund. Tourists often visit these hot springs to take a dip, believed to have therapeutic properties, especially after the arduous journey.

Cultural Exploration: Badrinath and its surrounding areas are rich in culture and heritage. Tourists can interact with locals, experience their traditions, sample local cuisine, and shop for handicrafts and religious artifacts.

Adventure Activities: For adventure enthusiasts, Badrinath offers opportunities for trekking to places like Valley of Flowers and Hemkund Sahib, which are renowned for their scenic beauty and alpine flora.

Accessibility: Badrinath is well-connected by road, and the journey itself is an adventure, with winding roads offering panoramic views of the Himalayas. However, due to heavy snowfall in winter, the temple remains closed from November to April, making summer and early autumn the best times to visit.

Overall, a trip to Badrinath is not just a tourist experience but a spiritual and cultural journey that leaves a lasting impact on visitors.

Badrinath, the temple is a collection of Bodh Shilpa Shauli type temples. It also has a hot spring where devotees go to worship the Lord after bathing.

Vyas Cave is believed to be the place where sage Vyas composed the Mahabharata epic with the help of Lord Ganesha. He also composed 18 Puranas, Brahma Sutras and four Vedas. Maharishi Vyas statue is installed in the caves and worshiped by the pilgrims. Vyas Caves is located in village Mana on the banks of River Saraswati. Here you can see Vyasadev's 5331years old Rock Inscription (Shila Lekh).

Vyas Cave is one of the historical, mythological and religious tourist attraction and a must see place to visit while on Badrinath Dham pilgrimage. It is located 5km from Badrinath.

This Holy cave is now 5331 years Old now. You will be able to notice some specialties of the cave when you visit the place. One thing I would like to share which I felt and confirmed with the panditji available there that the temperature inside the cave is warmer in winter and he told me it stays cooler in summer. You will also be able to see the Amazing and the oldest statue of Lord Ved Vyas ji who dictated the great Granth's like Mahabharata and many other to Lord Ganesha from this cave.

Bheem Pul is a natural stone bridge that is located in a village called Mana, which is near to Indian side of the Indo-Tibet border and is designated as the First village of Uttrakhand. It is just  3 to 4 km away from Badrinath temple and is also the meeting point of the Saraswathi and Alaknanda rivers. Due to this, one can also hear the gushing waters of the Saraswati River right below this huge stone structure.

According to the story, Pandavas, who are well known as Pandava Brothers, in the epic Mahabharatha, followed this very path when they walked their final journey from Badrinath temple to Swarga (heaven), also known as the Swargarohan.

But, Draupadi, the wife of the Pandavas, was finding it difficult to cross the Saraswati river. So, at this point, Bheema, who was supposed to be very strong and possess the strength of several elephants, brought a big Shila or stone and placed it above the flowing Saraswathi river.

This single piece of stone was so perfectly placed and covered the area so well, that it acted as a bridge, and Draupadi could cross the river easily.

We visited Char dham Yatra on September 23 by car. Bhim pul is built over the Saraswati river. It is 5 km from Badrinath temple. Local vehicle available @ rs. 50/ person up to mana parking area.

Mana Village, India’s last village before the Indo-Tibetan border:

Mana Village stands as a testament to India’s natural beauty, cultural richness, and historical significance. Nestled in the northernmost part of the Chamoli district in Uttarakhand, this remote Himalayan paradise is steeped in myth and legend. Here are the highlights:

How to Reach:
By Road: Take a bus or hire a taxi from Rishikesh or Haridwar. The scenic route passes through picturesque towns like Rudraprayag, Joshimath, and Badrinath.
By Trekking: Adventure enthusiasts can trek approximately 3-4 kilometers from Badrinath. The trail winds through lush forests and pristine landscapes.
By Helicopter: For those with limited time, a helicopter ride from Dehradun to Badrinath is an option, followed by a taxi to Mana Village.
Best Time to Visit:
Summer (April to June): Pleasant weather with temperatures ranging from 15°C to 25°C (59°F to 77°F). Ideal for exploring the village and trekking routes.
Unique Experiences:
Tea from the Last Tea Shop of India: Sip tea while gazing at the Neelkanth Peak.
Saraswati River: Flows by the village, adding to the serene ambiance.
Mana Village is a place where tiny houses line narrow lanes, women knit woolen clothes, and sustainable living thrives. It’s a feeling of being one with nature—a must-visit for travelers seeking authenticity and adventure! 🏔️🌿

Mana village is situated near the Indo-Tibetan border and is one of the last villages in India. Mana Village is famous for its many things like woolen garments and materials shawls, caps, muffler, ashan, pankhi etc.

How To Reach Badrinath
By Flight- The nearest airport is that of Jolly Grant, which is about 305 km from Badrinath. Helicopters and small private airlines are allowed to land there.
By Rail - The nearest railheads are Rishikesh (289 km) and Kotdwar (318 km), connected to Haridwar, Dehradun, and others in Uttarakhand. We would provide you with all India tourist permit vehicles for the local transportations and intercity drives.
By Road - Badrinath is connected to cities in Uttarakhand and significant cities in India by a motorable road. Buses are available from ISBT Kashmiri Gate in Delhi to Rishikesh, Dehradun, Haridwar, and more. Tourism of India provides guided tours you can book for a hassle-free Badrinath tour.

Best Time To Visit Badrinath
Plan your Badrinath between May to June and September to October. The weather is pleasant, making your Badrinath visit an enjoyable affair. Also, it is never too hot, even in the summers, with night temperatures falling to as low as 10°C. This makes it a pleasant retreat from the other tropical places in the country. reviews.text: Saraswati River is named after the goddess of wisdom.  This river is also known as GuptGamini or Hidden River as it flows just around 100 m from its origin and then merges into river Alaknanda at Keshav Prayag in Mana.

We have visited Char dham from 15.9.23 to 28.9.23 by car. The origin of Saraswati river is 5 km from Badrinath temple in Mana the last Indian village. Hindu belief that Saraswati is still underground & meets Yamuna river Yamuna & Ganga at Hyderabad. Originating in the high Himalayas, the Saraswati is believed to have descended to the plains from Adi Badrinath.
Now Saraswati temple near bhim pul is under construction at the originating place of Saraswati river in Mana village. Ved Vyas gufa & bhim pul is nearby. Vasundhra fall track,  satopanth track & swarga rohini track passing on the bhim pul.
Bhim pul belongs to pandvas i.e.Mahabharat period. Historical place as well as natural calm.

Mana Village is a beautiful and quaint hamlet nestled in the lap of the majestic Himalayas, located in the Chamoli district of Uttarakhand state, India. It is situated at an altitude of 3,200 meters above sea level, making it the last inhabited village on the Indian side before the Tibetan border

Saraswati river originated from  between two mountains and the water flows just  0.5 - 1 km to the main entrance of Mana village then only 3km joint the Alaknanda river, Badrinath temple. Saraswati river also the hidden river of Indian historical, geographical and mythological. 2022 started a new temple dedicated to Mata Saraswati, left side of saraswati river.

The Saraswati River rises between two mountains, travels 1 km to Mana Village's main entrance, and finally joins the Alaknanda River at Badrinath Temple in just 4 km. The Saraswati River is also known as the Hidden River in Indian geography and history. On the left bank of the Saraswati River, construction of a New temple began in 2022.
